pt: {sc}standard{/sc} {sc}criterion{/sc} {sc}gauge{/sc} {sc}yardstick{/sc} {sc}touchstone{/sc} mean a means of determining what a thing should be. {sc}standard{/sc} applies to any definite rule, principle, or measure established by authority.
{sc}criterion{/sc} may apply to anything used as a test of quality whether formulated as a rule or principle or not.
{sc}gauge{/sc} applies to a means of testing a particular dimension (such as thickness, depth, diameter) or figuratively a particular quality or aspect.

pt.t: polls as a {it}gauge{/it} of voter dissatisfaction

pt: {sc}yardstick{/sc} is an informal substitute for {sc}criterion{/sc} that suggests quantity more often than quality.

pt.t: housing construction as a {it}yardstick{/it} of economic growth

pt: {sc}touchstone{/sc} suggests a simple test of the authenticity or value of something intangible.

pt.t: fine service is one {it}touchstone{/it} of a first-class restaurant

quotes.t: The broadest {qword}gauge{/qword} of the economy—the gross domestic product, adjusted for inflation—has risen little more than 4% since the recovery began.

et: Middle English {it}gauge, gage{/it} "fixed standard of measure," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}gauge, gouge{/it} "standard of liquid measure, tax paid to an official who determined the capacity of containers" (continental Old and Middle French {it}jauge{/it} "graduated rod used for measuring liquid capacity, measurement by such a rod, capacity of a cask"), perhaps going back to Old Low Franconian {it}*galga{/it} "rod, beam," going back to Germanic {it}*galgōn{/it} "pole, stake, pole on which a condemned person was hung"; (sense 4) translation of German {it}Massstab{/it} {ma}{mat|gallows:1|}{/ma}

The semantic supposition behind this etymology is that the Old Low Franconian etymon retained the sense "rod" (lost elsewhere in Germanic) which was specialized to refer to a kind of measuring rod in Gallo-Romance. For detailed argumentation and bibliography see {it}Dictionnaire étymologique de l'ancien français{/it} (online) at entry {it}jauge.{/it}
